Award.AwardTitle: LTREB Renewal - Collaborative Research: Responses of high elevation, aquatic ecosystems to interannual climate variability and trends in atmospheric inputs
Award.AbstractNarration:
Long-term investigation of Emerald Lake and neighboring lakes and watersheds in the Sierra Nevada (California) are transforming our understanding of how mountain ecosystems are responding to global change. The proposed research will test the hypothesis that altered climate, changing snow regime, and changes in atmospheric composition are driving biogeochemical and ecological changes in high elevation ecosystems. Data to test this hypothesis will come from studies of lake metabolism, continued assessment of the response of lake phytoplankton to changing atmospheric deposition, continued study of the coupling between climate variability and nitrogen and phosphorus biogeochemistry, enhanced measurements of atmospheric deposition, and paleolimnological study of lake sediments. This research will build on more than two decades of biological, meteorological, hydrological, and chemical measurements in high elevation sites.

Management of National Parks and Wilderness Areas in the Sierra Nevada will benefit from the results of our research. The analyses and reconstructions will provide valuable information to Federal and State scientists on long-term lake changes and likely future responses of high elevation aquatic ecosystems to climate change. This research will provide training for one graduate student at UC Riverside in the interdisciplinary study of paleoclimatology and one graduate student at UC Santa Barbara. There will be active recruitment for these students at Minority Serving Institutions of higher learning. A strong outreach program developed with Woodlake High School in Tulare County (Central Valley agricultural region) will be expanded using field experiences and data from the proposed paleo-investigations and climate reconstructions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
High-elevation, snow-dominated lakes and watersheds are widespread throughout western North America and elsewhere in the mountains of the world. California?s iconic Sierra Nevada, John Muir?s ?range of light?, harbors thousands of remote, high- elevations lakes, and few have received sustained study.  Hence, our long-term and intensive studies in the high-elevation lakes and watersheds of the Sierra Nevada are rare and have added considerable understanding about these ecosystems and their management. In the high-elevation Sierra, most of the precipitation falls as snow, and large inter-annual variability in snowfall occurs, with the wettest year on record having 10 times as much snow as the driest year. The majority of the stream flow occurs during snowmelt, and passes through numerous lakes on its way to supply California with most of the State?s water.  Outflow solute concentrations are strongly influenced by the accumulation and melting of the seasonal snowpack with a pulse of high nitrate often during snowmelt. Biological and chemical processes in the watersheds generate 2 to 5 times more cations than are deposited via atmospheric deposition. Our investigations have demonstrated that Sierra lakes responded to acidic deposition early in the 20th century and that the Clean Air Act has had a positive effect on the continuing recovery of these lakes from acidic deposition.  While examining N cycling we discovered that saturating levels of nitrogen may not occur in alpine ecosystems that undergo abrupt seasonal transition and leak nitrogen.  We observed during the past four decades, that air temperature at Emerald Lake, a representative high-elevation lake in Sequoia National Park, warmed at an annual average rate of 0.86 oC per decade, but no significant warming occurred in lake temperatures because almost all the variation in lake temperature was regulated by the amount of snow in the watershed. However, reductions in spring snowpack and earlier melt would increase the chances of lakes warming in the 21st century.  Meteorological and hydrological instrumentation and resulting measurements at high-elevations in the Sierra Nevada are quite rare, yet important to allow assessment of water resources and climatic conditions. Our sets of such instrumentation represent some of the only significant infrastructure at high-elevations of the Sierra Nevada.

Training of graduate students and postdocs in limnology and watershed science has been a major objective of our project. Through the entire lake and watershed study (1983-2018), more than 30 M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees were based on data from the Emerald Lake watershed and other Sierra watersheds and have generated more than 200 peer reviewed publications and a book.  More than 100 young people were employed on the project since its inception in 1983, including about 3 dozen summer interns and undergraduate participants since NSF funding began in 2003. Engaging under-represented University of California students in our field studies and Woodlake high school students with real-world applications of mathematical and statistical techniques has increased these students interest in STEM fields. We have interacted with hundreds of private citizens, while at our field sites in the Sierra Nevada or in public talks or in classrooms at the University of California and Woodlake High School.
